name: lignite power plant construction | lignite power plant | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/851/documentation

This dataset represents the components of a coal power plant, based on two specific reference coal power plants with 100 MW and 500 MW. The dataset represents a mix with a share of 30 % and 70 %, respectively. 

From pasture land forseen for the construction of a coal power plant.

This activity ends with a constructed coal power plant. The datasets includes apart the materials necessary for the construction of the hard coal power plant also the construction efforts, land use as well as the disposal of all materials.
category: F:Construction/42:Civil engineering/422:Construction of utility projects/4220:Construction of utility projects

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: German data for the end of the 1980s and US data for early 1980s.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The coal power plant is installed with an electrical filter and a flue gas desulfurization (DeSOx). Additionally a selective catalytic reduction (SCR) takes place and a DeNOx plant is installed. In the old federal states of Germany 70% of electricity production was produced from lignite power plants within the capacity class 500 MW. This value is assumed for all UCTE countries. It represents an average technology in 1980s.;Reference:;RWE (1993) Personal communication, RWE Energie AG, Essen.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Based on literature data for coal power plants.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=RER
The materials depend on the capacity, fuel used, applied environmental technology and local conditions. Local conditions in particular, determine the amount of concrete for the foundation and the construction effort for the cooling tower and storage yards.
As a base load power plant the lignite power plant achieves 6’000 fully load hours per year. The high number of operation hours occurs, since lignite power plants are operated often for two or three years without interruption and then followed by a larger maintenance. A number of 200’000 fully load hours in total are assumed. This corresponds to a lifetime of 38 years. 
The lifetime is a conservative estimate, since coal power plants may be operated 50 years or more. The fact that coal power plants are modernized several times during their lifetime is not considered. That would cause an additional material consumption. However, increases the lifetime and reduces the material consumption per generated unit of energy. Due to large mass flows, lignite power plants are built larger. This results in a higher material consumption per MW. Due to the higher lifetime, this effect is compensated again.

exchanges.description:
Estimation. General information on land use of coal power plants can be found in (Jensch 1988), (VDI 1993), (Jacobs et al. 1981), (GEK 1978), (OECD 1985), (DOE 1983), (IAEA 1991) and vary from 100-3700 m2/MW. The largest deviations arise from the consideration of landfill sites for ash and residues from flue gas cleaning. In the U.S., these are deposited on the plant site. In Europe, the values vary from 100-600 m2/MW. Important influencing factors are the size of the coal storage, capacity of the plant, applied method of cooling , use of environmental technology, area available and the chosen boundary. These values are also confirmed by exemplary values for environmental statements (HKW Heilbronn 2002), (RDK 2000). 60m2 per MW are assumed for building area and 80m2 per MW for traffic area, whereby traffic area is assumed for the tanks of the power plant (CORINE 121a). The area is derived from 6’000 fully load hours per year resp. 200’000 fully load hours in total. For lignite power plants the coal storage area is eliminated since it is operated as a mine-mouth plant and there are only little if no storage facilities available.

Further references:
VDI (1993) Instrumente zur Minderung energiebedingter Klimagasemissionen IKARUS. VDI Bericht 1043. Tagung Schliersee, 29./30. Apri 1993, Schliersee, Deutschland.
DOE (1983) Energy Technology Characterizations Handbook; Environmental Pollution and Control Factors. U.S. Department of Energy. Washington, D.C.
Jacobs H., Kreutzer A., Pleyer H., Stoll A. (1981) Grundflächenbedarf von Kraftwerken. In: Siemens-Energietechnik 3 Heft 8-9, s. 298-302.
GEK (1978) Die Umweltbelastung im Energiebereich. Schriftenreihe der Eidg. Kommission für die Gesamtenergiekonzeption, Studie Nr. 24, Bern.
OECD (1985) Environmental Effects of Electricity Generation. Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development/International Energy Agency, Paris.
IAEA (1991) Senior Expert Symposium on the electricity and the environment. Helsinki 13-17 May 1991, Vienna.
RDK (2000) Rheinhafen-Dampfkraftwerk Karlsruhe. Umwelterklärung 2000. Energie Baden-Württemberg AG, Karlsruhe.

defaultProvider.category: E:Water supply; sewerage, waste management and remediation activities/38:Waste collection, treatment and disposal activities; materials recovery/383:Materials recovery/3830:Materials recovery

exchanges.description:
Estimation. General information on land use of coal power plants can be found in (Jensch 1988), (VDI 1993), (Jacobs et al. 1981), (GEK 1978), (OECD 1985), (DOE 1983), (IAEA 1991) and vary from 100-3700 m2/MW. The largest deviations arise from the consideration of landfill sites for ash and residues from flue gas cleaning. In the U.S., these are deposited on the plant site. In Europe, the values vary from 100-600 m2/MW. Important influencing factors are the size of the coal storage, capacity of the plant, applied method of cooling , use of environmental technology, area available and the chosen boundary. These values are also confirmed by exemplary values for environmental statements (HKW Heilbronn 2002), (RDK 2000). 60m2 per MW are assumed for building area and 80m2 per MW for traffic area, whereby traffic area is assumed for the tanks of the power plant (CORINE 121a). The area is derived from 6’000 fully load hours per year resp. 200’000 fully load hours in total. For lignite power plants the coal storage area is eliminated since it is operated as a mine-mouth plant and there are only little if no storage facilities available.

Further references:
VDI (1993) Instrumente zur Minderung energiebedingter Klimagasemissionen IKARUS. VDI Bericht 1043. Tagung Schliersee, 29./30. Apri 1993, Schliersee, Deutschland.
DOE (1983) Energy Technology Characterizations Handbook; Environmental Pollution and Control Factors. U.S. Department of Energy. Washington, D.C.
Jacobs H., Kreutzer A., Pleyer H., Stoll A. (1981) Grundflächenbedarf von Kraftwerken. In: Siemens-Energietechnik 3 Heft 8-9, s. 298-302.
GEK (1978) Die Umweltbelastung im Energiebereich. Schriftenreihe der Eidg. Kommission für die Gesamtenergiekonzeption, Studie Nr. 24, Bern.
OECD (1985) Environmental Effects of Electricity Generation. Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development/International Energy Agency, Paris.
IAEA (1991) Senior Expert Symposium on the electricity and the environment. Helsinki 13-17 May 1991, Vienna.
RDK (2000) Rheinhafen-Dampfkraftwerk Karlsruhe. Umwelterklärung 2000. Energie Baden-Württemberg AG, Karlsruhe.
